speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the nature of the pain you're experiencing? Is it a sharp, stabbing pain or a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a sharp, stabbing pain, it came on really quickly while I was playing football, and it feels like it's in my lower left side, but it's moving around a bit.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the location of the pain, is it centered around your belly button or does it radiate to either side or downwards?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to pinpoint, it's more like it's centered around my lower left side, but it's moving around, like it's shifting down towards my hip. It's a bit hard to explain, it feels like my stomach is... twinging, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical examination. Can you please stand up and bend forward at the waist, so I can assess the abdominal muscles and look for any tenderness or guarding.

speaker: Patient
text: I can do that, doc. I'll just bend over. *bends forward*

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me, has this pain been constant, or did it come on suddenly, as you've described?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been going on for about two hours now, so it's not really constant, but it's been getting worse over time. It started when I was playing football, and I thought maybe it was just a cramp or something, but then it got worse and I knew I needed to come in.

speaker: Doctor
text:
The patient stands up and bends forward at the waist, and I can see that their abdominal muscles appear tense, with some mild guarding in the lower midline. I notice a slight tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant.

Can you tell me, when did the pain start, and was there anything that triggered it, such as eating, lifting, or bowel movements?

speaker: Patient
text: I think I must have eaten something that didn't agree with me, but I don't know, it's hard to say. I had a sandwich for lunch about an hour ago, but I don't think that's what caused it.

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me, have you experienced any recent changes in your bowel movements, such as diarrhea or constipation, and have you noticed any blood in your stool or urine?"

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I don't think I've had any issues with my bowel movements recently. I've just been having a lot of trouble with, uh, peeing after exercising.

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Can you tell me if you've experienced any fever, chills, or sweating, which could indicate an infection? 

And have you recently traveled or been exposed to anyone who's been ill?"

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so, doc. I've been pretty healthy, just been dealing with this pain all day. I did play a game of football last night, and we had a few guys who weren't feeling well, but I didn't think much of it at the time."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the nature of the pain you're experiencing now, is it more intense or has it decreased in severity since we started talking?



Also, I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: The pain you're experiencing is still sharp and stabbing, but it's not as intense as it was initially. It's more of a dull ache now, and it's shifted its location down towards your hip, as you described. The movement of the pain is still present, but it's not as severe as it was when you first arrived.

speaker: Doctor
text:
The Complete Blood Count results are in. I'd like to review them with you. 

Can you tell me, when was the last time you urinated, and have you noticed any blood in the urine?



Is the pain in your left lower quadrant constant or does it come and go?



Have you recently taken any medications or supplements that could be contributing to your symptoms?



Also, can you describe the sensation of the pain further, is it a dull ache, or does it feel like it's pressing or squeezing?



I'd like to perform a digital rectal exam to assess for any tenderness or abnormalities in the rectum.

speaker: Patient
text:
I've been trying to go to the bathroom, but it's been really hard. I've only managed to go a few times, and even then, it was just a little bit.

The pain is still there, but it's not as sharp as it was. It feels more like a dull ache, and it's mostly in my left side, but it's still shifting down towards my hip. It doesn't really come and go, it's more like it's always there, just changing location a bit.

I haven't taken any new medications or supplements, I'm still on my asthma meds, though. And the pain feels like it's pressing, like there's something pushing on my insides.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've reviewed the Complete Blood Count results, and I see that your white blood cell count is slightly elevated, indicating some inflammation in the body. I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Urinalysis.

Also, I'd like to take a closer look at the rectal exam, can you please relax your pelvic floor muscles for me?



And can you tell me, have you experienced any recent changes in your menstrual cycle or fertility issues that could be related to your symptoms?



Also, have you noticed any weakness or heaviness in your legs or lower back?



Please, let's take a closer look at the rectal exam.

speaker: Measurement
text:
RESULTS: The pain you're experiencing is still present, but it's more of a dull ache and less intense in terms of sharpness. It's mostly in your left side, but it's still shifting down towards your hip, and there's a feeling of pressure or something pushing on your insides. You've been having difficulty urinating, and you've only been able to go a few times since the pain started.

Please proceed with the requested tests and examinations.

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Thank you for the patient's relaxation, I'm going to gently insert the gloved finger into the rectum. Please bear with me for just a moment. 

Can you tell me, do you have any history of previous surgeries, particularly in the abdominal or pelvic area?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so, doc. I've never had any major surgeries, but I do have a small scar from a childhood appendectomy, if that counts."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'm going to take a closer look at the rectal exam results and review the patient's overall presentation. 

I'd like to ask, can you tell me, have you experienced any bowel movements since the pain started, and if so, were they normal or did they change in any way?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, my bowel movements have been a bit off since the pain started. I've only been able to go a few times, and even then, it's just been a little bit of a trickle. I'm not sure if it's the pain or something else, but it's definitely not normal."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've reviewed the rectal exam results and noticed some tenderness and mild inflammation in the rectum. I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound of the abdomen. 

Also, I'd like to ask, have you experienced any recent changes in your sexual activity or any new sexual partners that could be related to your symptoms?

text:

Also, I'd like to ask, have you experienced any recent changes in your bowel habits, such as frequent urination or changes in stool consistency?

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Okay, I'd like to review the biopsy results with you now. Can you tell me, have you noticed any discharge or fluid leakage from the affected area?



Also, have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to the abdomen or lower back?



I'd like to ask, have you noticed any changes in the color or consistency of your stool, or any changes in the amount of gas or bloating you're experiencing?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I haven't noticed any discharge or fluid leakage from the affected area, doc. I don't know if that's possible, but I'm not aware of anything like that. As for trauma, I did fall on my side while playing football, but I don't think it was anything serious, just a bruise or something."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've reviewed the biopsy results, and I'm going to take a closer look at the images. It appears that we have a likely diagnosis. 

Can you tell me, have you noticed any recent changes in your bowel movements, such as diarrhea or constipation, and have you noticed any blood in your stool or urine?



Also, I'd like to ask, have you experienced any recent changes in your sexual activity or any new sexual partners that could be related to your symptoms?

Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs or feet?

DIAGNOSIS READY: Ovarian Cyst or Ovarian Torsion
